so what is usability
how easy it is to use your product yeah so it's that effectiveness um
how how well the product is at doing what it says it's supposed to do the problem
it's supposed to solve there's also the efficiency of the product a lot of people get these two can
confused but efficiency is essentially how much you can do with the product without waste
so to to show you the difference between those if you have a row boat that is sinking right you can have the most
efficient water baling process it's just all motion nothing wasted
but it might be more effective to patch the hole difference there we also have our
learnability might be a made up word essentially that's how easy the product is to pick up and learn
and then we have our safety a lot of people get this one confused they think like well the product's not going to hurt me or shock me and that's true but
what also might we think of when we're talking about safety and feeling safe while using a product
yeah you're not introducing harms yes unintended side effects absolutely
also could be the security of your application it should also be if you know where you are and how to get out
and if you make an error how can you recover from that so all
that is part of the user's safety memorability is how well you can remember a product
and come back to it so if you're using a product daily and then you go on a holiday for two weeks and then you
come back and you can't remember how to use the product or you need a refresher that generally has a low memorability product and that memorability comes in
place depending on how often your users are going to use that product you need to kind of keep that more in mind of
that learnability and memorability playing together and then finally there's that satisfaction how it how
satisfying or good is it to use to meet your needs okay so we talked about usability what's
user experience and don't say usability
yeah so it's how the product feels the experience that they're actually having while using the product so a lot of
people get usability and user experience confused and it's easy to do that usability is how easy the product is to
use how effective how efficient etc the experience is the overall experience that you are having while you're using
that product so you could have a completely usable product that no one wants to use okay that would be a low ux
product so i asked one of my developer friends i said can you tell me in your mind what
the difference between ux and usability is and he got pretty close he said usability is the saddle in
the stirrups and user experience is how it feels to be on the horse and that's sort of kind of
correct so a lot of people also confuse the usability with the user interface and to
give a whole talk on that so i'm a little nervous now but the the user interface is all those things the
user is interacting with right the usability is how effective efficient satisfying those things are to use for
instance with the saddle it could be does it fit you well is it ergonomic um
how does it feel that way but the actual user experience is when i'm on the horse i'm generally not on the horse just to
sit on top of a horse unless i'm a royal but i could be on the horse that didn't go well i could be on the
heart trying the american humor doesn't work here this is all right no big deal
you could be on the horse generally to go somewhere or to do something it could just be a touring experience or you
could be plowing a field or you could be going somewhere so that's the experience on the horse
all right so always start with the user goals and the business goals so i want you to
think about your product and most people can answer this one pretty well what is a business goal of your product
making money well it's very generic but yes absolutely we want to make money yes
fix web development what else what do you what does your business want to do with your product
what is their goal help more people
yeah so making sure that you understand what your business's motivation and why they're making this product is key
and then you also want to think about your user goals why are there using your product are they using your product to make you
money is that their goal generally not right
no they have their own motivations they generally have a problem that they're trying to solve that they want to use your product to solve
so what we do in ux is we're trying to find that overlap between those business goals and those user goals we want to
find the return on the investment for the company and the return on experience for the user that return on experience
is key because that's going to keep them coming back for more because if they don't have that good return on experience as soon as a
competitor product comes in and it has a better experience they're generally going to switch over right
so that's really where you get that value now there's a third bubble here that's technical feasibility uh whether
that be for your team or the in the area at large what can you actually do
so good ux is built around users we start with our users first those user goals and obviously we need to make
money so we need to marry those with our business goals in order to start with our users we have
to understand what our users need and we do that through a variety of methods called user research
so user research identifies who our users are what they're trying to accomplish and
what constraints they're working on it could be cultural constraints it could be environmental constraints it could be skill levels i work at union pacific
railroad it's the largest railroad in north america and so i work with a lot of internal users
and we live essentially in an outdoor factory right the railroad is constantly moving in all sorts of conditions so my
environment may be very different than the environment you might be
developing for it could be you know on a mobile phone in the middle of nowhere we have to have
an offline mode and it needs to work while you're in a standing in a blizzard or it could be in a nice cushy office
environment with your standing desk and your bottle of designer water what have you so they're
different environments and skill levels also what are they currently doing to
solve whatever problem they're solving now is it an unsolved problem or do they have something currently involved what's
their current process what are problems and workarounds with the current process what bugs them right
now a lot of times these are invisible to users they don't exactly know what their workarounds are they just know
this is how they get things done and then the successes and necessities of their current process
a lot of people in user research especially if they're new to user research and they're replacing an existing product they sometimes forget
to look at this and it's really important to understand what your previous product did well
why why do you want to understand what your previous product did well
so you can evaluate it next against the new process right you want to see what your your users already love about your
product because if there's something they already love a specific feature or a specific way something is done yes you
can improve it but you need to make sure you keep that in mind and that you need to be selling them on that next process
the way i think of things is if it's not three times better it's worse
why they need to relearn stuff and change
and learning is hard especially if it's not any better right then it just feels like a chore i'm forcing you to do

techniques um to inject ux there might be five i don't know how to count it's
early in my time zone uh so we're going to first go up with the six up so six up is essentially just
sketching something six different ways so when you're first evaluating a design you're trying to figure out how to solve
a problem a lot of times people will sketch something out and they'll go with whatever they first thought of and what
i like to do is i like to stop myself take a piece of paper draw six sextants
i used to call them quadrants but apparently that's not right it's sextants because there's four of them
uh you can see i've been shamed on the internet um so i go through different sections so
i'm like i might have a drop down we might have a radio button i might do a select component so you're starting to
go through and as you go through it starts getting harder and harder to think of other ways to do this
and you continually sketch and try to figure out what how different ways you do it out you
might get really out of the ballpark on that fifth and sixth but often what happens is i don't just select one i
figure out what works with each of these and i might combine them and decide on something new i might go with my first
solution but i might not and what it's forcing me to do is just look at the problem a little bit more
intensely so that's a six up very simple way to do things
the next tip is to design iteratively what does iteration mean
trial now yes cyclical right so if i'm designing something iteratively that means it's not just
done once and this is preached a lot in the product mindset of those of you that are doing like agile methodology
methodology especially with that product mindset it's that you start with something and you don't have that waterfall
approach of this is exactly where we're going and then we're going to hum down the waterfalls as we go there and this
we're always marching toward the exact same thing and it's never changing because the market is going to change
things change um your goals change so we want to make sure that as that's happening we are also iterating on it
and we're not just going with our gut instinct the next thing would be to do user interviews
we call them go and sees in the railroad and the reason why we call them go and sees is because contextual interviews
didn't sell well so we would tell our users we want to go do a go and see which is essentially a shadowing
we watch them work we note their processes and we use this have them teach me or a master apprentice approach
uh with your interviews i'm gonna i have a whole workshop on this but we're gonna go through this first thing you wanna do
is identify your biases so before you interview anyone write down all of the assumptions that you have
and be aware that you have those assumptions so as you're taking notes actually in this interview make sure
you're saying am i actually observing this or am i just trying to
find this solution i just i have this thing that i want them to say and i'm trying to pull that data from them so
make sure that you identify your biases so you can see where you might accidentally be leading uh your analysis
leave your assumptions at the door so identify them and try to leave them out and then try to avoid leading questions
so what's an example of a leading question why do you think this is hard why do you
think this is hard why do you think this is hard why is that a leading question
what have i done yes i've implied that it's hard another leading question might be
would you prefer a or b why is that a leading question
what about the rest of the alphabet that's right so with a lot of these leading questions they often aren't
intended they could be something as simple as uh could you find the the login button
asking someone just too specific a question rather is you want to be asking them
about kind of their goals the 9010 rule has anybody heard of the 9010 rule in user interviewing
maybe what's the 80 20 rule
yes it's they should be doing 90 of the talking so you're there to listen
so uh 90 of the talking should be done by then 10 should be done by you so it's not a normal conversation where you're
trying to give equal weight and you want to talk about what's happening now to a spaceball's reference
we're in now now okay and the reason why we want to talk about the present is people are terrible at
predicting their future actions when i packed for ndc i said you know what
i am going to jog every morning and i brought five pairs of jogging pants and
how many of those five pairs of jogging pants have i used none because i can't seem to get myself
out of bed in this time zone but we're terrible at predicting but we are good at talking about what's
happening now and we are good about reflecting on past behaviors so for example
people might be struggling and you might say well wouldn't you just click on the help
button well one i just led them and two they're probably going to agree with me and they said yes of course
but then you would follow up with how often in the past have you clicked that help button
and if the answer is zero that's more likely your answer
all right so we use generally the master apprentice model so this is you
and this is your subject even if you have so much subject matter expertise in
this your goal is to give them that role that power they are the one that is teaching
you okay all right so that is user interviews in a nutshell next thing is usability
testing i love usability testing what this does is you're essentially having a prototype and tasks which are
essentially goals not click on the login button we're not giving them instructions we're saying you know we
want you to um create your own profile or whatever probably wouldn't use the word profile
because that also could be a keyword note where they get stuck and note where they succeed so when you're doing this
you want to let them do the talking similar to interviewing you want to remain as neutral as possible watch your facial features
if they can see that they're doing well or poorly i always start with them is this is a test of the design not of you
so there is no passing or failing of this test we're simply seeing if the design is intuitive and needs to be used
and if we're having trouble that's not your fault so we do not lead or provide the user
training we simply provide them with a task of goals and we have them speak their thoughts aloud walk me through as you were doing
this tell me what you're looking for what you're seeing what you're thinking do not defend the design now this is the
hardest number one thing for a lot of people to do is when they see someone having trouble the first thing they want to do is provide
training or help and the second thing they want to do if they're receiving criticism is defend why they made that design design decision that doesn't
matter because when you are presenting someone with a product are you going to be
sitting with every single user that uses that product
hope not yet no you're not and so therefore you can't really defend it to everyone so you
might be able to convince one user but that's not really going to solve your problem find out why they struggled
why they succeeded and improve on the parts they struggled on
testing in a nutshell a lot of people say i do usability testing but they're really talking about one of these other
things they might be talking about functional testing or a focus group where they bring everyone in
and they demo it they could be talking about only working with business partners the people that are funding and having them play with it

what i do here is i show a screen and then i give an example so uh the reason why you're showing a

of sticky notes and a marker generally of their own color and they're just silently write down say
for the next you know five to seven minutes however however complex the screen is you might need to give them more time
write down some notes that you have any questions that you have about the designs any concerns you have about the designs any feedback write those down
and they'll stick them on the whiteboard you can also do this remotely i use a tool called miro that one's pretty good

at time you you give time and then you get all the sticky notes to

each one of these post-it notes and we'll have discussion about them and what that does for our stakeholders
is everyone feels heard because we we invite our tech users we invite our smes
we invite some of our business partners and we might invite some user reps as well the actual users in the field
and everybody has equal weight everybody has the same amount of post-its everybody has the
same type of marker and we'll go through all of them and that really gives that buy-in that they feel heard now does that mean that you
